sub_title: Ministry of Infrastructure and Water Management / Rijkswaterstaat
summary: Cor Schipper was involved in several European research studies EU FP6, EU FP7, as Modelkey, MESMA, MSFD, Blue Growth, Vectors, OCEANS, Interreg. He participated in European marine organisations e.g.  OSPAR, ICES, SIME, PIANC and IMO.  He was involved in international networks of organisations on environmental and sediment management studies like Dutch-German-Exchange programme, European Biodiversity, NORMAN, SedNet and EuDa. He has published over 20 scientific articles (H index= 19; http://scholar.google.nl/citations?user=n7pPt-UAAAAJ&hl=nl ) on the topics of environmental geochemistry, marine policy and ecotoxicology, of which several focus on the environmental risk assessment. He was representative of the Central Dredging Association (CEDA), the OSPAR Working Group on the Environmental Impact of Human Activities (EIHA), and was coordinator of MESMA Black Sea Marine Spatial Planning. He  was member of the PIANC-IAPH working group 174 ‘Sustainability reporting for ports’ to implement Green Port development. Last years he is working as expert on Nature Based Solution projects as Marker Wadden Lake IJssel and Coastal Genesis Amelander Zeegat, in THe Netherlands and EU Interreg C5A a climate adaptation project. Several publications have been made on the Sustainable Development Goals with focus on a wide range of global climate pressures in coastal areas. Now he is programma manager of the nourishment of Galgeplaat flat in the Eastern Scheldt, The Netherlands. Due to reduced tidal amplitude and flow, the building-up of tidal flats by tidal currents has reduced, which results in erosion of the flats. This has led to loss of intertidal habitats and increasing wave loads on the dikes. The Eastern Scheldt intertidal areas Galgeplaat and ROggenplaat are especially important as foraging grounds for birds and seal habitat. Because of its nature value the Eastern Scheldt is a Natura2000 area and managed as a Natural Park.

projects.title: Development Nature based Solution of intertidal flat Galgeplaat
projects.description: Nourishment on the Galgeplaat, one of the biggest intertidal areas in the Eastern Scheldt, The Netherlands.

contributors.headline: Ministry of Infrastructure and Water Management / Rijkswaterstaat

projects.title: ‘Juego serio Puerto de Futuro’ /Port of the Future is launched for use in Latin America
projects.description: Deltares has launched a Spanish version of the serious game Port of the Future ’Juego serio Puerto de Futuro’. The ‘Puerto del Futuro’ serious game will allow the Dutch Embassies in Latin American countries to facilitate dialogue, raise awareness of the current policy challenges for ports, and help port stakeholders to achieve sustainable development. The ‘Juego serio Puerto de Futuro’ provides showcase solutions for resilient and sustainable port development that can be tailored for port authorities and stakeholders in the region. Some examples of more sustainable solutions are given, including clean shipping, safety, sustainable dredging, aquaculture and sand nourishment.During a two-day course at Deltares, three employees from the Peruvian, Panamanian and Chilean embassies received training as port game facilitators from seven Deltares experts.

contributors.headline: Ministry of Infrastructure and Water Management / Rijkswaterstaat

projects.title: Integrated and sustainable port development in Ghana within an African context/NWO
projects.description:
Activities associated with port development, as land reclamation and implementation of infrastructure may have a negative impact on ecosystems and socio-economic functioning. Recent initiatives such the Sustainable Ports Guidance of PIANC and IAPH suggest to move away from the traditional approach and adopt interventions as an opportunity to create added value instead. Such interventions require a successful balance between morphological, economic, ecological and social processes. This proposal builds onto that knowledge to apply and develop it in African context aiming integrated and sustainable plans and designs for African ports. The approach is interdisciplinary, in co-creation with (African) stakeholders and develops bottom-up from practical cases into tools and a generic framework for African ports. Specific aspects for the African context will be addressed in Ghana within the Port of Tema pilot study, and compared to and expanded using other relevant African cases, thus creating generic knowledge and tools which will be applicable in African port development projects. A growing consensus recognises the need to shift economies and social structures towards more integrated, sustainable, inter-disciplinary approaches aimed at finding the right balance between human, environmental and economic aspects of development. However, traditional port development often requires activities such as land reclamation, dredging and building new infrastructure, which generally have a substantial negative impact on local and regional ecosystems.
What is lacking is an integrated approach to sustainable port development, which embraces
the three perspectives of: 1) engineering, 2) ecosystem services and 3) governance. Such an
approach should also include knowledge of the underlying physical processes and (software)
tools to enable quantitative design.

contributors.headline: Ministry of Infrastructure and Water Management / Rijkswaterstaat

projects.title: Ports of the Future Serious Game/ Colombia, RVO, MinI&M, Boskalis, Royal HaskoningDHV, TUD, IMARES, Deltares
projects.description: To support the elaboration of a tailor made Port of the Future Masterplan for a specific port and to secure involvement of stakeholders, high-end tools are developed.We developed for that purpose the Port of the Future Serious Game. The aim of this game is to create support and awareness for the port development with all stakeholders. This includes the socio-economic development, natural requirements and impact of sustainable design. Of course this requires insight in cause-effect relations/chains. The application is useful for port authorities, planners, policymakers, NGOs, scientists, nature developers and citizens. The Green Port knowledge-based serious game can be further developed so that the complexity of the marine city-port area and port development will be integrated with fundamental knowledge developments.The game applies a fictional but realistic environment, autonomous (i.e. non-controllable) scenarios, a set of measures and a qualitative set of indicators for safety, economy and the natural environment. This framework is used and adapted to a fictional coastal port environment including its hinterland, both natural (e.g. river) and economic (city, transport). Also, a set of indicators is defined for port development is such a way that the effect and impact of a traditional port can be compared against a sustainable port development. Yet, port projects are confronted with a growing scarcity of prime locations and the uncertain impacts of climate change. Clearly, there is a need for innovative solutions for port development that is in harmony with the ecosystem and that is robust or adaptable under change.

contributors.headline: Ministry of Infrastructure and Water Management / Rijkswaterstaat

projects.title: Coastal Genesis 2.0
projects.description:
Sand nourishment has proven itself to be an effective and sustainable method to counter the effects of coastal erosion. Rijkswaterstaat has been implementing sand nourishment for many years and aims to further improve this approach to address rising sea levels. The Coastal Genesis 2.0 programme aims to answer three questions: How much sand will be needed in the long term to ensure that our coastal foundation keeps pace with sealevel rises? Where and when will that sand be needed? And what is the best way to add this to the coast? There are various reasons for ecological research in the
Ameland Inlet. First, researchers aim to establish the starting situation (baseline measurement) in order to determine the effects of the planned nourishment on the Ameland Inlet ecology. Furthermore, little is known about ecosystem functioning in tidal inlets. This Ameland Inlet research should make clear how marine animal populations recover following the pilot nourishment. This research will also expand our ecological and morphological knowledge of outer deltas. Ultimately, the research should provide insight into the most appropriate level and location for such nourishment in order to minimise  ecological impact.

contributors.headline: Ministry of Infrastructure and Water Management / Rijkswaterstaat

projects.title: H2020 Port of the FUture Project
projects.description: COREALIS proposes a strategic, innovative framework for modern ports to handle upcoming and future capacity, traffic, efficiency and environmental challenges. It respects the limitations that many European ports are facing concerning the port land, intermodal infrastructure and terminal operation. It proposes beyond state of the art innovations that will increase efficiency and optimize land-use/infrastructure, while being financially viable, respecting circular economy principles and being of service to the surrounding urban environment. Through COREALIS, the port will minimize its environmental footprint to the city, it will decrease disturbance to local population through a significant reduction in the congestion around the port. It will also be a pillar of economic development and business innovation, promoting local startups in disruptive technologies of mutual interest. COREALIS innovations are key both for the major deep sea European ports in view of the new mega-vessel era, but also relevant for medium sized ports with limited investment funds for infrastructure and automation

contributors.headline: Ministry of Infrastructure and Water Management / Rijkswaterstaat

projects.title: EU, Chile, Mozambique, Netherlands, Russian Federation: Green Port Development
projects.description:
The ultimate goal of our program is to achieve long term environmental, societal and economic benefits through resource conservation, waste reduction and pollution prevention. The design of a
new or extended port layout requires adequate attention to a number of aspects to guarantee both an efficient, healthy ecosystem, and sustainable port growth. The key to improvement in green port ability is to combine sustainable economic growth with environmental measures for an improved cost benefit strategy.

contributors.headline: Ministry of Infrastructure and Water Management / Rijkswaterstaat

projects.title: Ports of the Future/WWF
projects.description: The growing number of port development projects recognises the need to shift economies and social structures towards more sustainable models. World Wildlife Fund (WWF) like to know if the development of a new or extended port layout requires adequate attention to a number of aspects that guarantee both sustainable port growth as well as a healthy ecosystem functioning. There is a need for innovative solutions for port development which are in harmony with the ecosystem it lies in and which are robust or adaptable under change. In this study we discuss the sustainable and no-impact port development concept in co-creation with principles from morphology, infrastructure engineering, ecological and socio-economic perspectives. For sustainable and the no-impact port development, multidisciplinary criteria have been specified, based on functions of the coastal marine ecosystems. This study has considered port governance models and touched upon elements of financing ‘no impact ports’.

contributors.headline: Ministry of Infrastructure and Water Management / Rijkswaterstaat

projects.title: Assessment of ecological water quality in Dutch harbours
projects.description: The objective were to assess the water quality in Dutch harbours by: a). Relating epifaunal sensitivity to the presence of contaminants, thereby identifying suitable bioindicators;b). Linking these bioindicators to the established toxicant pressure (msPAF) in the relevant ecosystems; c).Using toxicological data to demonstrate and predict the impact of chemical contaminants on ecosystems. The method  was developed based on the international marine monitoring project SETL and applied in  7 Dutch harbours to monitor epifaunal abundance. Ten 14 ×14 cm PVC-plates attached to a floating dock were checked every three months. Surface water concentrations of PAHs, PCBs, insecticides, heavy metals and abiotic factors (temperature, salinity, pH, oxygen concentration, depth and flow rate) were measured. Multivariate statistics (CANOCO) and msPAF calculations were used to assess the suitability of indicators for contaminants and ecosystem health.The correlation between the msPAF and epifaunal bioindicators is a useful approach for assessing the environmental status and therefor also water quality.

contributors.headline: Ministry of Infrastructure and Water Management / Rijkswaterstaat

projects.title: Environmental impact assessment of dumping dredged sediments
projects.description:
The acute impact of dredging, covering and storage of sediment is in most cases more of a physical than of a chemical kind. However, most of the persistent,bioaccumulating and toxic (PBT) chemicals known to induce chronic sublethal effects (i.e. imposex and intersex) in gastropods are bound to the small sediment particles and transported to locations far away from the original dumping site. Given the potential chronic environmental consequences of these PBT chemicals and their bioaccumulation in the food chain, it is vital to improve the assessment of the full environmental risk from contaminants in disposed dredged material, including the risk for chronic effects at locations at a long distance away from the disposal site. International studies have shown Tributyltin (TBT) to be the most problematic of all the chemicals tested in the marine environment. Up till now, the impact of TBT on the ecosystem has been fragmentarily evaluated. The local impact can be studied by using local biological indicators. These bioindicators are local species whose population or health status can be used as a reference to determine environmental
vitality.

contributors.headline: Ministry of Infrastructure and Water Management / Rijkswaterstaat

projects.title: Green4Infra/Partners for Water / Mozambique
projects.description: The design of new or extended port and urban layout requires adequate attention to a number of aspects to guarantee both an efficient, healthy ecosystem, and sustainable growth. The concept of Green Infrastructure is central to sustainable growth strategies because decisions made within such a framework are long-lasting, more adaptive and resilient to change, environmental friendly, and more cost effective. In the development of sustainable cities, green port and marinas it helps to mitigate against climate changes induces sea level rise and increased storminess. Deltares has developed a masterplan in of the port of Beira in Mozambique with the strategy and direction towards sustainable development of the port. The ‘grey to green’ concept is new for port development. Deltares performs vulnerability assessments of ports and port areas in which sea level rise, green adaptation, eco-engineering and healthy ecosystems are taken into account. To cover all these critical aspects adequately it is essential to have a close cooperation with local and national authorities. In the port of Beira, the original focus on climate change effects was extended to a broad evaluation of environmental issues in the coastal zone. As such the project evolved from a climate-change oriented analysis towards a broader scope of environmental problems in the coastal zone.

contributors.headline: Ministry of Infrastructure and Water Management / Rijkswaterstaat

projects.title: Knowledge Base of the Dam Resilience Tool
projects.description: Structural interventions like dams may induce adverse hydraulic, geomorphological, environmental and social impacts in both upstream and downstream areas of river systems. Despite these impacts, the construction of dams remains inevitable, due to the increasing demand in energy, irrigation, recreation and flood protection, as well as the increased water supply. Therefore there is a growing demand for sustainable dams, which have no negative impact on the ecosystem. Sustainable  evelopment of dams can be achieved not only by setting regulation and guidelines, but also by raising awareness among stakeholders and policy makers about their optimal implementation and  ecessary measures to minimize the impacts.The main objective of the study is to develop a knowledge-based framework that evaluates impacts on resilience and sustainability measures. The key performance indicators and assessment of sustainability measures in the context of defined indicators are very sensitive part of this approach. This requires insight in to relevant physical processes, system analysis and impact assessment, which shall be quantified by making use of state-of-the-art tools, models and expert judgement.

contributors.headline: Ministry of Infrastructure and Water Management / Rijkswaterstaat

projects.title: Sediments as a source of pollution due to the release of emerging compounds
projects.description:
The advent of the Water Framework Directive and the introduction of the Water Act will place
the focus of the assessment of aquatic systems on the quality of surface water. This raises
the question of the extent to which aquatic sediments act as a source of pollution due to the
release of substances. This study examines whether substances are released from aquatic
sediments to the water column by means of diffusive transport, and the degree to which this
occurs. It also considers what routine or specialist methods are available to measure this
subsequent release of substances.
Three very different locations (IJmuiden, the Afferdensche and Deestsche Waarden, and the
Ghent-Terneuzen Canal) were sampled. A range of measuring techniques were used, and
experiments were conducted to quantify emission fluxes of organic compounds (PAHs,
PCBs), heavy metals and nutrients.
The results showed that substances are released by diffusion at all locations, and that in
some cases they partially determine water quality, and thus compliance with WFD quality
objectives. The main substances are phosphate, arsenic, zinc, lead, nickel and a number of
PAH and PCB compounds. At the three locations examined, PAH levels in surface water
exceed the WFD limit, mainly as a result of the release of sediment-bound contaminants.
It was found that, in order to determine fluxes on the basis of diffusion, some idea of the
concentration gradient over surface water and sediment is needed. This applies equally to
organic contaminants, heavy metals and nutrients. The redox-sensitivity of substances,
particularly at the transition between oxic and anoxic conditions, is very important. As a result,
none of the ‘routine’ techniques used was capable of giving a reliable impression of diffusive
emissions. Passive sampling (IVPS), Empore disk, SOFIE and modelling instruments were
the most suitable of the ‘specialist’ techniques.

contributors.headline: Ministry of Infrastructure and Water Management / Rijkswaterstaat

projects.title: Green Port Policy in Tanzania
projects.description:
Project type / client / call
World Bank, TMEA/Tanzania Port Authorities

Description
The aim of stakeholder involvement with ‘Development of a Green Port policy’ and implementation action plan, is to set in motion a process that results in an integrated and sustainable port development. By adopting the Green Port Action Plan a radical plan will be established aimed at significantly reduce health risks posed by emissions from port-related ships, cargo trucks, cargo-handling equipment and harbor craft.

The Deltares objectives’:
Important element in our approach is the organization of 2 workshops. The outcomes of these workshops
will be used as building blocks for preparing the Green Port Action Plan:
-Assessment of sustainable port development and green port policy; Assessment of current practice in the field of Green port policy, climate resilience and reducing carbon emissions in port management
-Training with port of the future serious game to create port stakeholder awareness. Priority implementation steps for Green Port policy objectives 
-Presentation final report with Input for the formulation of realistic policy goals for implementation in the future Green Port policy goals

contributors.headline: Ministry of Infrastructure and Water Management / Rijkswaterstaat

projects.title: Jeu sérieux Port of the Future
projects.description: Le jeu sérieux Port of the Future (jeu sérieux ou « serious game » en anglais) a pour but de former les joueurs et de prodiguer des conseils d'élaboration de politiques afin d'améliorer les performances des ports selon les trois indicateurs de durabilité suivants : les personnes, la planète et les profits. La découverte des différentes mesures de politique et de leurs impacts apportera une aide indispensable lors de la prise de décision dans un environnement portuaire changeant. Ce manuel fournit le contexte théorique et scientifique du jeu sérieux, les règles et le déroulement du jeu et décrit également les mesures et les indicateurs. Enfin, il comprend des recommandations pour les animateurs du jeu, ainsi que des outils de validation, comme un questionnaire axé sur les retours des joueurs.

contributors.headline: Ministry of Infrastructure and Water Management / Rijkswaterstaat

projects.title: ECOSTRESS
projects.description: ECOSTRESS will be focused on the search of better-integrated strategies through the strengthening of the risk prevention and disaster management cycle of the coastal zones. The key elements in the ECOSTRESS project are represented by the use of an ecosystem integrated approach to deliver societal benefit. The risk assessment of flooding hazard occurrence in the coastal lowlands system will be evaluated by taking into account the interaction of three elements of vulnerability: economic, ecological and social vulnerability. The idea is to promote an innovative approach in order to understand the processes occurring between ecosystem services and the value of natural capitals, for a valuable implementation of current management and conservation strategies. The analysis of the ecosystems resilience, their ability to cope with the impacts from natural hazards and to reduce the risk of damage, will be combined with the “adaptive capacity” of a community, element of social vulnerability. In ECOSTRESS is defined area of interest on the base of field visits and  understanding based on the analysis of reporting on the Northern Adriatic Italian test case and the Dutch Wadden Sea under the general context of water and flood management.

contributors.headline: Ministry of Infrastructure and Water Management / Rijkswaterstaat

projects.title: Develop and test methodology and criteria for assessing coherence, adequacy and representativity of European networks of marine protected areas/European Commision
projects.description:
In order to establish a methodology for assessment of coherence and representativity, one
needs also to take account of other issues, for instance, Member States (MS) are bound by Europenian Union (EU) legislation, while the process of appointing Marine Protected Areas (MPAs) and how to prioritize among different uses of an area are determined by national data availability and criteria. The identification of commonalities in MS approaches and information used in establishing MPAs will provide the necessary information for developing the next steps towards a more coherent harmonized network of MPAs on EU level, supporting the Good Environmental Status aim.

contributors.headline: Ministry of Infrastructure and Water Management / Rijkswaterstaat

projects.title: EC/The implementation of the Marine Strategy Framework Directive (2008/56/EC)
projects.description: In this study several documents were prepared that provide the scientific background for the implementation of the Marine Strategy Framework Directive (MSFD) in the Netherlands. It provides information that is pertinent to the Initial Assessment required by Article 8 of the MSFD. This report describes the environmental conditions in the Dutch part of the North Sea, the current human activities and the associated predominant pressures on the ecosystem. It also describes the present environmental status in terms related to eleven qualitative descriptors for Good Environmental Status from Annex I of the MSFD. A social and economic analysis that will form part of the Initial Assessment is being carried out by the Centre for Water Management (Rijkswaterstaat) and will be published separately. The other two reports deal with the determination of characteristics of Good Environmental Status (GES), required by Article 9 of the MSFD, and the  establishment of indicators and environmental targets as specified by Article 10 of the MSFD. In the report establishment of Indicators and Environmental Targets the interrelationship between the 3 reports is presented.

contributors.headline: Ministry of Infrastructure and Water Management / Rijkswaterstaat

projects.title: Monitoring, Evaluation and implementation of Spatially Managed marine Areas (MESMA)
projects.description:
Within MESMA, nine case studies represent discrete marine European spatial entities, at different
spatial scales, where a spatial marine management framework is in place, under development or considered. These studies are chosen in such a way that they encompass the complexity of accommodating the various user functions of the marine landscape in various regions of the European marine waters.

authors.headline: Ministry of Infrastructure and Water Management / Rijkswaterstaat
Ministry of Infrastructure and Water Management / Rijkswaterstaat
Ministry of Infrastructure and Water Management / Rijkswaterstaat

profile_positions.description: In 1986, a storm surge barrier and compartmentalization dams were built in the Eastern Scheldt tidal basin in The Netherlands as part of the Delta works. As a result, the dynamic morphological equilibrium of the basin has been disturbed. Intertidal flats are now confronted with the so called ‘sand hunger’ or sand starvation: due to reduced tidal amplitude and flow, the building-up of tidal flats by tidal currents has reduced, which results in erosion of the flats. This has led to loss of intertidal habitats and increasing wave loads on the dikes. The Eastern Scheldt intertidal areas are especially important as foraging grounds for birds. Because of its nature value the Eastern Scheldt is a Natura2000 area and managed as a Natural Park. As a mitigation measure, intertidal flats of Roggeplaat and Galgeplaat will be nourished with sediment to conserve foraging grounds for birds. Goal is to reduce the impact of sand starvation under sea level rise to preserve the ecological functions (i.e. low-water foraging function of bird species) in reference year 2010 for the following 25 years and at the same time prevent undesirable wave impacts.
profile_positions.title: Project Manager development Nature Based Solution Galgeplaat

company.name: Ministry of Infrastructure and Water Management

profile_positions.company: Ministry of Infrastructure and Water Management
profile_positions.description: Flood Management in the Netherlands has been successful the last decades, because of adaptive changes made by authorities, legislations, and in financial and governmental processes. Flood Risk Management and Water Management are integrated in many countries e.g. the Netherlands, France, UK. Schipper is working as an advisor at Ministry of Infrastructure and the Environment in projects for the development of coastal and offshore regions. One of his specific interests and expertise area relates to projects to assess the impact of climate change on the physical system, in a wider framework of Integrated Coastal Zone Management, Green Coast Policy and Disaster Risk Reduction Management. In Interreg C5A is analysed the experience of stakeholders and practitioners in experimenting and evaluating the novel “Cloud to Coast” framework to climate change adaptation. The framework combines a whole-system, inclusive and adaptive approach facilitated with a continuous dialogue in order to accomplish resilient societal outcomes
profile_positions.title: Advisor Senior Marine Ecology, Green Coast Policy and Water Management

profile_positions.description: PhD at Unit Marine and Coastal systems, Department Water Quality and Ecology, Deltares, Delft, the Netherlands.Cor Schipper is at Deltares PhD senior marine biologist who has been involved for more than 25 years in field and experimental studies related to environmental geochemistry, marine biology, ecotoxicology, marine policy and sediment risk assessment studies. He finished his PhD thesis in sediment management and ecotoxicology research at the Wageningen University on the assessment of effects of chemical contaminants in dredged material on marine ecosystems and human health.  He has a broad experience in impact assessment studies of emerging compounds in the environment, the impact assessment studies of hazardous compounds e.g. PCB’s, TBT and dioxins on marine invertebrates and fish in the aquatic environment, the risk of thermal discharge and storm water runoff on marine species in the nearby environment. As a senior marine biologist he develops knowledge, innovative products and services for the European Union on topics as EU Blue Growth, EU Marine Strategy Framework Directive and concept of ecosystem services in dredging and marine construction.  Throughout the world, advanced expertise enables safe, clean and sustainable living in deltas, coastal areas and river basins. The concept of WB Green Growth enables him to study the sustainable port ('Port of the Future' concept) and urban ('City of the Future' concept) development in where economic progress fosters environmentally sustainable and low-carbon, inclusive development.
profile_positions.title: PhD Senior researcher marine biology/expert sustainable port development/ecotoxicology

profile_positions.description:
As CEDA representative is involved in OSPAR Environmental Impact of Human Activities (OSPAR/EIHA) on the assessment of human activities in the context of biodiversity and ecosystems and management considerations of the MSFD. CEDA activities can be summarised as follows: 
-Provide an independent  forum where all those involved in any kind of activity related to dedging and marine construction can meet and discuss dredging issues 
-Generate and disseminate quality, impartial knowledge and information about all aspects of dredging to those who either want it or need it.
profile_positions.title: CEDA representative in OSPAR Environmental Impact of Human Activities

profile_positions.description:
Coordinator of the Black Sea case study in which to analyse the governance structure of the Black Sea member states and the role of marine spatial planning in relation to marine nature protection. Studied is the governance structure in the Black Sea region and the use of Marine Spatial Planning (MSP) as a means of marine nature protection. It describes the strengths, limitations, flaws and possibilities of the current governance structure in the Black Sea region in relation to MSP and marine nature protection. 
Six countries have a Black Sea shoreline: Bulgaria, Romania, Ukraine, Russian Federation, Georgia, and Turkey. Bulgaria and Romania are EU countries and as such are obliged to follow EU regulations.
profile_positions.title: Coordinator Black Sea region marine spatial planning

profile_positions.description:
National Institute for Coastal and Marine Management, Netherlands, (RIKZ).
Given the potential environmental consequences of chemical exposure by the disposal of
dredged material worldwide, it is vital that we improve our understanding of its impact on the
environment. Through an improved understanding we can minimize the risks associated with the
disposed dredged materials.Chemical and biological analysis of dredged material indicates potential hazards and provides a means to quantify the risk when also bioavailability is taken into account and ecologically relevant endpoints are being studied. The estimated risk and current sediment quality criteria, however need to be validated by performing local impact assessment upon licensed disposal of dredged harbour sediment. Bioassays with local sediment may provide insight into the bioavailability and mixture effects of chemicals from the dredged material. In addition, a wide variety of bioindicators can be used to determine the effects of sediment-associated chemicals and tohighlight adverse effects overlooked by the risk assessment for the local ecosystem at or beyond the disposal site. This might facilitate improved ecological risk assessment of dredged sediments for the receiving marine coastal ecosystem. Sediment-associated persistent, bioaccumulating and toxic compounds in dredged material mostly accumulate downstream of the disposal site due to transport of the contaminants bound to small particles. To identify effects of the chemicals, bioassays and biomarkers are needed that relate ambient sediment chemistry data to specifi c potential adverse biological effects.
profile_positions.title: Senior project leader Marine Sediments

profile_positions.description: The laboratory conducts research into geo-chemistry and biochemistry carried out during surveys of the chemical and biological monitoring program at the Dutch Continental Shelf. Initiating biochemical and toxicological laboratory innovations and managing laboratory workers. Responsible for the management system into compliance with ISO 17025 (Sterlab accreditation) and maintaining the QA /QC recognition.
profile_positions.title: Researcher

profile_positions.description: Nowadays, The Netherlands Cancer Institute accommodates approximately 650 scientists and scientific support personnel. It is the only dedicated cancer center in The Netherlands and maintains an important role as a national and international center of scientific and clinical expertise, development and training. Studied was the working mechanism of fusion noninvasive, non-metastatic  T-lymphoma cells with normal T-lymphocytes, since it usually resulted in highly invasive and metastatic T-cell hybridomas.
profile_positions.title: Researcher molecular biology

profile_positions.description: Studied chondrocytes in the in-vitro high density model respond to a mechanical stimulus of physiological magnitude. The chondrocytes respond to intermittent compresive force by an increase of glycosamineglycans in matrix proteoglycans with hyaluronic acid.
profile_positions.title: Researcher biochemistry
